title: Trump teases quick China deal and downplays need for using strategic oil reserves
text:
Getty Images President Donald Trump waves from Air Force One after landing in Mountain View, Calif., for fundraising events.

President Donald Trump on Tuesday said a trade deal with China could be struck soon, as he downplayed the need to tap the U.S. Strategic Petroleum Reserve after the weekend attack on Saudi Arabian oil facilities.

CHINA DEAL

Speaking to reporters aboard Air Force One, Trump said there could be a deal with China “maybe soon,” and also that it could come before, or one day after, the 2020 election.

As he has previously, he leaned on Beijing to make a deal with him before the election, saying terms would be better. “If it’s after the election, it’ll be the toughest deal anybody’s ever had to make from the standpoint of China, and they know that,” Trump said.

SPR

Trump, in California for fundraisers, also told reporters he didn’t see the need to use the SPR to stabilize oil prices.

“I don’t believe I need to, but if we want to use strategic oil reserves, I would open them up,” he said.

Saudi Arabia’s energy minister, Prince Abdulaziz bin Salman, said his country’s oil production will be fully back online by the end of the month. October West Texas Intermediate CLV19, -0.83% oil fell 5.7% Tuesday after rising nearly 15% on Monday. November Brent crude BRNX19, -0.60% traded down 6.5%.

Now read: Here are the 3 key times the U.S. tapped into its massive emergency oil reserves.

Trump was scheduled to speak in Portola Valley, Calif., at the residence of former Sun Microsystems Inc. CEO Scott McNealy on Tuesday for a fundraiser luncheon expected to haul in $3 million before heading to Beverly Hills for a similar function.

See: Trump and Obama both set to visit Silicon Valley this week.

LEWANDOWSKI

Trump on Twitter thanked his former campaign manager Corey Lewandowski for what he called a beautiful opening statement during the House’s first impeachment hearings. Democrats complained during a judiciary committee hearing that Lewandowski was giving no answers to their questions.

The hearing came after the White House late Monday sent Chairman Jerrold Nadler a letter saying Lewandowski was barred from discussing his conversations with Trump beyond what has been made public from former special counsel Robert Mueller’s report.
